page.title: 17THE RIBBLE MARSHES
page.content: Part of our survey area is covered by the Ribble marshes. In all, this National Nature Reserve covers an area of 2302 hectares of saltmarshes and intertidal flats. It occupies a key position in the Ribble Estuary which is of international importance for birds. In 1979, the Nature Conservancy Council purchased 2182 hactares toi save it from being embanked and converted to arable land. 120 hactares of the part of Hesketh Out Marsh was embanked in 1980. About half of the area is greenmarsh and is grazed by cattle during the summer and half is mudflats and sandbanks. The reserve has a full time warden and a team of voluntary wardens. It is managed by the north west region of the Nature Conservancy Council. The reserve was aquired to protect the habitat of waders, ducks, geese, gulls and terns
